options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: N/A
Zoom
Weekly meetings w/ regular discussion, speakers, and one time debate

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
knowledge: major actors, power dynamics, and areas for reform in global health
skills: clearly expressing your ideas in written and spoken format
insights: the roadblocks to reform in any political sphere
Very interesting discussions and learned a lot about the interactions between policy/politics and health systems

Incredibly relevant course material, especially given that we are in the midst of a global pandemic. I learned a lot about the political landscape of global health and relevant historical events and policies that gave way to this current landscape. You also get to choose your own research topic for a lot of the assignments, which I really appreciated.
The political context surrounding global health progress. I learned how to question the status quo in the field, and better understand the levers necessary for change.
Through the readings, discussions, and guest speakers, we touched on not only important, background material on global health, but also the deeper, more complicated issues facing it.

I drastically expanded my understanding of the role of governments in the health of the world's population. I became incredibly excited about the intersection of politics and medicine, which is regularly overlooked. I was encouraged to question what public health decisions are made around the world. I became more confident in my reading, discussion, and debating abilities.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
strengths: lots of opportunity for discussion and room for personal improvement over the semester,  insights into so many different subfields and types of assignments, nice mix of class presentations and open discussion. Well-balanced with talking about Covid-19/election and historical examples, involved but not bogged down by readings. 
weaknesses: sometimes jumped around a little too much
I love it!
A very strong, well-organized course. I appreciated the opportunity to hear from additional experts in the field. I wish we could've shared the topics of our final papers with each other.

Professor Kerry's deep experience in the field added such an interesting component to our discussions--we not only learned about the issues facing global health, but also got to hear about how they manifest in her work/experience in the field. Overall, it was a great class, made great by the professor, the deeply engaging course material, and peers.

Strengths: small size, intense discussion, engaging professor, continued support/resources
Weaknesses: N/A

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: N/A
Very engaging zoom sessions
I wish we could have met in person, but this course worked fine in the virtual format.

The virtual discussion did not hinder the intensity of conversation as much as expected. This success was largely a result of the professor's engagement and excitement. I believe students could be engaged more by employing the Zoom react features to get all students involved during discussions.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: 110%: you get a thorough introduction to the politics of global health and learn how to enter the national conversation on making health reform.
Yes!!
Definitely. Class discussions pushed me outside my comfort zone and I feel like I learned a lot.
YES! Kerry is such a wonderful professor and fosters a lot of great discussions that don't get talked about enough.

Absolutely! This course explored a valuable intersection for future physicians, researchers, and politicians. I believe the mixture of government and health is too often ignored, and this course does a good job of peeling away the complex layers.
